##### I have finally reached the pinnacle!

I have been tinkering with website page speed optimization for years, although never really giving it the focus that it deserved. I regularly use sites like [Google Page Speed](https://developers.google.com/speed/pagespeed/insights/ "Google Page Speed"), [GTMetrix.com](http://gtmetrix.com/ "GTMetrix.com"), [YSlow](http://yslow.org/ "YSlow"), and [Pingdom](http://tools.pingdom.com/ "Pingdom"). Over the years, with an analysis tool like Google Page Insights, most sites I built generally averaged in the mid 70s, maybe peaking at 80/100 on desktop and forget about mobile. Mobile analysis would generally range around the high 60s if not worse. 

Don't get me wrong, I cared about it and always did what I could to optimize images, etc... but at the close of a project and deployment, I'm generally ready to take a break. I always use the excuse, I'll get back to the optimizations later.. but of course that never happens. 

> Now, page speed and micro-optimization has become an obsession. 

As of 10:05am this morning, I reached the summit of the mountain, a perfect 100/100 on Google Page Speed and an average of mid to high 90's on GTMetrix and YSlow for almost all of my personal blog's pages. My home/index page doesn't quite score as high due to having embedded pens from [CodePen](https://codepen.io "CodePen") and some other various API calls to Twitter and LastFM. Those eat up some of my score, but for the most part are out of my control. Every other page on my site scores either 100/100 or mighty darn close. 

For those of you who dabble in page speed tweaks and enhancements, it's not an easy task to get there. It's a stealthy combination of image optimization, caching, compression, and many other micro optimization techinques. 

######Google defines it's Top 10 requirements as:

- Enable compression
- Leverage browser caching
- Optimize images
- Minify HTML
- Avoid landing page redirects
- Eliminate render-blocking JavaScript and CSS in above-the-fold content
- Minify CSS
- Minify JavaScript
- Prioritize visible content
- Reduce server response time


It's also handy to use some of the tools within Chrome Dev Tools to do micro optimizations for page paint times, loading, etc. The Network tab in Chrome can be your best friend in trying to determine speed suck holes.

######A few tricks from my bag:

This is nothing new, and nothing that hasn't been covered on the web before, but here are some of my recent methods to help you push your site up to that coveted number. 

**Reduce HTTP Requests** You can use Chrome Dev Tools as well as many other tools to easily see how many HTTP requests your site is pulling for any given page. Every image, every style sheet call, every javascript call, results in a request. Reduce these! Combine/concat your javascript, combine/concat your CSS/SASS, use [SVGs](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scalable_Vector_Graphics "SVGs") for simple icons, basic logos, etc and use [Base64 URIs](http://jpillora.com/base64-encoder/ "Base64 URIs") for more complex images or photos.

**Include an .htaccess file** in your root to help with browser caching, etc.

**Minify** your Javascript, SASS/LESS, and your HTML. There are a lot of work flows and tools to do this, but my favorite is using a task runner like [Gulp](http://www.gulpjs.com "GulpJS") or [Grunt](http://gruntjs.com "Grunt"). 

With these tools, you can set up automated tasks to do all of those tasks for you before deployment.
